Award.AwardTitle: A quantitative analysis of heuristics and discounting models of intertemporal choice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discounted Utility model has, historically, been regarded as the appropriate model of how people make choices between intertemporal prospects (e.g., between receiving some amount of money today versus that amount of money plus interest at some future date.) However, there is abundant evidence that actual behavior systematically departs from the predictions of the model. A variety of alternatives have been proposed in the literature. Some of these depart from Discounted Utility's assumption of exponential discounted while others assume that intertemporal choices are made based on the application of simple decision heuristics. In this research project, the PI (in close cooperation with Dr. Jeffrey R. Steven's lab at the Center for Adaptive Behavior and Cognition at the Max Planck Institute for Human Development, Germany) will develop full-fledged probabilistic specifications of competing theories for intertemporal choice and apply quantitative methods immune from aggregation artificacts to test their relative veracity.

Intertemporal choices underlie many of society's most pressing decisions, from collective decisions such as global climate change and the war on obesity to more personal decisions such as consuming alcohol and investing in retirement plans. Virtually all decisions we make have a temporal component. This makes intertemporal choice relevant across a broad range of disciplines (e.g., economics, psychology, biology, neuroscience, finance, medicine, environmental science). Despite the extensive interest in this topic, there still is a critical gap in our knowledge of how individuals make intertemporal choices. The research proposed in this application is significant because it will allow us to investigate the different cognitive processes that individuals use when making intertemporal choices.  Equally significant is the question of interindividual differences. Rather than dismissing variation as noise in the data, we expect to show strong qualitative differences among different people. In terms of broader impacts, this may  allow simple ``nudges'' to help people make better decisions by customizing individual decision scenarios to focus on the long-term benefits of a healthy lifestyle, a secure financial future, and environmental stewardship. The scientific findings will impact future training of basic and applied decision scientists. By eliminating major sources of artifacts, the project can help improve all levels of societal decision making in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intertemporal choices underlie many of society's most pressing decisions, from collective decisions such as global climate change and the war on obesity to more personal decisions such as consuming alcohol and investing in retirement plans. For the last 75 years, the study of intertemporal choice has focused on the discounting approach in which individuals subjectively devalue, or discount, future rewards because they are not available immediately. Despite the popularity of this idea, few researchers have explored the cognitive processes of intertemporal choice to determine if this really is how people make these decisions.  This project tested an alternative to the standard model that researchers use to explain intertemporal choices. The alternative approach does not discount but uses similarity judgments to make these choices. For example, $100 and $105 may be considered similar, whereas receiving money now vs. in a year might not be considered similar.

This project has accomplished its aims to (1) develop models of intertemporal choice that model variability and uncertainty in people's decision making, (2) generate simple rules of thumb for intertemporal choices, and (3) employ cutting-edge statistical techniques to test heuristic (simple rule of thumb) and discounting models. To achieve the first aim, the team developed new ways to mathematically specify models that can properly account for observed fluctuations in people's decision making. For the second aim, the team measured similarity judgments to develop heuristics that can account for intertemporal choices. Finally, the team conducted millions of computations to test a broad array of intertemporal choice models. The team found that rather simple models performed well, but variation across people and across repeated choices had important influences on which models best predicted choices.

In addition to achieving its scientific goals, this project also had broader impacts in software resources and training.  This project further developed earlier software to help researchers conduct the sophisticated statistical tests needed to properly compare intertemporal choice models. The software is publicly available. Finally, this project provided training opportunities for five graduate students and four undergraduates in the Regenwetter and Stevens laboratories as well as for a large number of junior scholars who attended an international workshop.  The graduate and undergraduate students learned the basics of developing experimental designs, collecting data, and analyzing massive data sets in multiple ways. Three of the undergraduates participated in the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates experience in which two computer science majors and one psychology major were cross-trained in both disciplines by a psychology faculty member and a computer science faculty member. The public training effort occurred as a part of the Workshop on Testing Theories of Choice Behavior that the team hosted in Berlin, Germany. More than half of the 80 participants, including the 30 poster presenters, were junior scientists from 14 different countries.  The junior researchers had the opportunity to attend talks on research results and methods, present their own work, and interact with senior researchers at the poster sessions and coffee breaks.  The team received praise from numerous junior researchers about how much they learned at the workshop and how they would incorporate into their own research the new skills they had learned.  The workshop was immensely successful as a training opportunity.
